FACILITY AND INVESTMENT PROGRAM SUMMARY 
Borrower  India

Investment Program  The Investment Program is designed to improve the quality of life of 
Description  urban  residents  and  promote  sustainable,  efficient,  and  responsive 
service  delivery  in  the  urban  areas  of  Uttarakhand.  The  physical 
investments  include  rehabilitation  and  expansion  of  systems  for  (i) 
water  supply,  (ii)  sanitation  and  sewerage,  (iii)  solid-waste 
management,  (iv)  roads  and  transport,  and  (v)  slum  upgrading,  in 
about 31 urban centers of Uttarakhand. Physical improvements are 
coupled  with  a  capacity  development  program  to  support  the 
implementation of the urban governance, finance, and service-delivery 
improvement action plan, and to strengthen institutional capabilities of 
urban local bodies and other service providers.  
   
Multitranche  The Government of India (the Government) has requested the Asian 
Financing Facility    Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  extend  financing  for  the  Investment 
Program through a multitranche financing facility (MFF). The requested 
MFF  amounts  to  $350.0  million  to  finance  the  infrastructure 
investments, capacity development, and the expenditures associated 
with Investment Program management. 
   
Rationale  A core objective of the Government’s 10th Five-year Plan (2002–2007) 
and the Approach Paper for the 11th Five-Year Plan (2007–2012) is 
reducing  interstate  disparities.  Uttarakhand,  as  one  of  the  less-
developed states, is prioritized for investments in urban infrastructure 
to  support  the  growth  of  the  state’s  leading  economic  sectors  of 
tourism and industry, and to cater to the needs of a rapidly growing 
urban population. A major thrust of the Government’s urban policy is 
the  74th  Constitutional  Amendment  Act  of  1994  which  promotes 
decentralized  urban  governance.  With  the  recently  announced 
Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban Renewal Mission (JNNURM), the 
Government  reaffirms  its  commitment  to  sustainable  urban 
development  through  linking  capital  investments  to  reforms.  At  the 
state  level,  the  Uttarakhand  government’s  urban  policy  and  plans 
reiterate those of the national strategies and reflect increasing outlays 
on  urban  infrastructure.  More  importantly,  the  Uttarakhand 
government’s initiation of major urban reforms and the signing of a

ii   
memorandum  of  understanding  with  the  Government  to  implement 
comprehensive  reforms  under  the  JNNURM  demonstrate  the 
Uttarakhand government’s commitment not only to developing physical 
infrastructure but also to sustainable service delivery.  
 
The  Investment  Program  has  been  guided  by  the  above  policy 
framework, and aims to provide critically needed urban infrastructure 
and  services.  It  combines  capital  investments  with  support  to  the 
Uttarakhand  government’s  urban  reform  action  plan  to  ensure 
sustainable outcomes. The Investment Program targets selected urban 
centers which will lead industrial and tourism growth while contributing 
to the reduction of poverty.  
   
Impact and Outcome  The expected impact of the Investment Program is improved quality of 
life for the urban residents of Uttarakhand. The expected outcome is 
increased access to better quality urban infrastructure and services for 
about 3.8 million people projected to be living in Uttarakhand’s 31 
urban areas by 2016.

for  the  next  10  years  under  the  Uttarakhand  Urban  Sector 
Development  Road  Map  is  around  $1.5  billion,  out  of  which  the 
proposed Investment Program accounts for around $500.0 million.

Executing Agency  The  Urban  Development  Department  (UDD)  of  the  Uttarakhand 
government  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  (EA)  for  the  Investment 
Program.  
   
Implementation  UDD,  as  the  EA,  will  be  responsible  for  overall  management  and 
Arrangements  monitoring of the implementation of the Investment Program through 
an investment program management unit (IPMU). Investment program 
implementation units (IPIUs) will be established (i) in Uttarakhand Pey 
Jal Nigam (the water utility) as the implementing agency for water 
supply  and  sewerage  component;  and  (ii)  the  Public  Works 
Department  as  the  implementing  agency  for  roads  and  traffic 
management component. IPIUs will be accountable to, and report to, 
the  IPMU.  Urban  local  bodies  will  be  given  a  major  role  in 
implementing  the  solid-waste  management  and  slum  upgrading 
components under the supervision and support of the IPMU. They will 
also be closely associated with design and implementation of the road 
and transport subprojects.  
   
Procurement  All goods, works, and services under the Investment Program will be 
procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as 
amended  from  time  to  time).  International  competitive  bidding 
procedures will be used for civil works contracts estimated to cost 
$10.0 million or more, and supply contracts valued at $1.0 million or 
higher.  The  upper  limit  for  civil  works  and  goods  to  be  procured 
through national competitive bidding procedures will be less than $10.0 
million  and  $1.0  million  respectively.  Shopping  will  be  used  for 
procurement of goods worth $100,000 or less.  
   
Consulting Services  Consultants  will  be  engaged  to  support  the  management  and 
implementation of the Investment Program in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007 as amended from time to 
time). Program management consultants will be appointed to support 
the IPMU in (i) managing, appraising, and packaging subprojects into 
tranches;  (ii)  monitoring  the  implementation;  (iii)  approving  detail 
design  and  procurement;  and  (iv)  overseeing  the  design  and 
construction. Design and supervision consultants will also be recruited 
to  assist  IPIUs  in  preparing  detailed  design  and  contract 
documentation, and construction supervision. Moreover, consultants 
will  be  recruited  to  design  and  conduct  capacity  development 
programs.  The  services  of  nongovernment  organizations  and 
community-based  organizations  are  also  likely  to  be  required  to 
support  (i)  civic  awareness,  (ii)  community-level  solid-waste 
management, (iii) slum upgrading, and (iv) monitoring of resettlement 
activities. It is estimated that a total of about 39 person-months of 
international consultancy inputs and 1,871 person-months of national 
consultancy inputs will be required for program management, detailed 
design, and capacity development activities.    
   
Project Benefits and  The  Investment  Program  will  benefit  about  3.8  million  people  (the 
Beneficiaries  estimated  population  of  the  Investment  Program  cities)  by  2016 
through an improved urban environment, with a resulting improvement 
in the health, living conditions, and productivity of the city residents. 
The  cities’  economies  will  benefit  from  enhanced  productivity  and

urban  efficiencies  resulting  from  better  urban  infrastructure  and 
services. Improved infrastructure and services will equip the cities to 
better cater to the needs of the industries and tourism which drive the 
Uttarakhand economy. All Investment Program interventions will either 
directly or indirectly benefit poor people. About 300,000 slum residents 
will directly benefit from the slum improvement component. Further, 
the Investment Program will ensure sustainable urban development 
through  supporting  urban  reforms  and  capacity  development  for 
improved  urban  governance,  finance,  and  service  delivery.  The 
cumulative  impact  will be  reduced  disparities  between  Uttarakhand 
and the rest of India.  
   
Risks and  The  main  risks  are  related  to  Investment  Program  implementation 
Assumptions  performance and the sustainability of investments. These include (i) 
slow Investment Program implementation, which is a common feature 
of urban sector projects; (ii) availability of land for locating assets (e.g., 
landfill  sites)  and  delays  in  obtaining  land  from  government;  (iii) 
delayed  actions  on  governance,  finance,  and  the  service-delivery 
improvement  action  plan;  (iv)  reluctance  in  levying  and  collecting 
increased user charges; and (v) inadequate public willingness to pay 
for the services, which presents a risk to sustainability.   
 
Risks for slow Investment Program implementation will be mitigated by 
establishing an IPMU and IPIUs as efficient units with qualified staff 
supported  by  consultants.  ADB’s  recently  approved  grant-funded 
component bridging technical assistance for Project Implementation 
and Capacity Building Support for Uttarakhand (2007) will also provide 
support to (i) familiarize UDD and implementing agencies with ADB 
procedures, (ii) help in consultant recruitment, and (iii) prepare the first 
tranche subprojects.  
 
Shortage of available land for landfill sites due to the need to protect 
forest land will be addressed by introducing innovative systems such 
as waste minimization at source, composting, and developing common 
landfill  sites  for  clusters  of  towns.  Delays  in  obtaining  land  from 
government  will  be  minimized  by  (i)  appropriate  sequencing  of 
tranches which involve components and/or subprojects requiring land, 
and (ii) taking actions sufficiently in advance to acquire land.  
 
Implementation of the urban governance, finance, and service-delivery 
improvement action plan is not expected to present a great risk due to 
the reform-minded Uttarakhand government, and the ownership by the 
state, ULBs, and utilities of the reform agenda under the JNNURM 
program. Civic awareness programs will stimulate demand for utilizing 
improved  services  and  increase  recognition  of  value  attached  to 
improved services among urban residents. The capacity development 
component of the Investment Program to be implemented under the 
first  tranche  will  further  facilitate  the  implementation  of  envisaged 
reforms.  These  will  be  complemented  by  ADB’s  continued  policy 
dialogue during program implementation.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to India for the Uttarakhand Urban Sector Development 
Investment Program (the Investment Program). The design and monitoring framework for the 
Investment Program is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES   
A.  Sector Description and Performance 
2.  The state of Uttarakhand, separated from Uttar Pradesh in 2000, is one of the new and 
relatively less-developed Indian states, and, as a result, is classified as a “special category” 
state. It is located on the northern boundary of India, and shares international borders with the 
People’s Republic of China and Nepal. It has a total land area of 53,483 square kilometers. 
Over 90% of the state’s terrain is hilly and 62% is forested, limiting the availability of land for 
agriculture. The state’s population is 8.48 million (2001). The literacy rate (83%) is much higher 
than  the  national  average  while  health  indicators  lag  behind  the  average  national  health 
indicators. About 25% (or 2.29 million) of the state’s population live in 63 urban areas. Although 
the current urbanization rate is less than the national average (28%), the urban growth rate 
during 1991–2001 was more than 1.5 times the growth rate of the state’s total population. 
According to official estimates, this rate will be sustained, and by the year 2026 over 37% of the 
Uttarakhand population will live in urban areas, making it the seventh-most urbanized state in 
India.  
 
3.  While Uttarakhand suffers from growth constraints and limitations in agriculture as a 
result of its hilly terrain and high forest coverage, these natural assets, combined with cultural 
and religious heritage, offer immense opportunities for tourism development. The state has a 
rich cultural and natural landscape, a wealth of major shrines and spiritual centers, and the 
sources  of  the  Ganga  and  Yamuna  rivers,  which  are  major  tourist  attractions.  Tourism  is 
currently the mainstay of the economy and a major source of employment. In addition to its 
tourism potential, the state has a bright outlook for industrial growth owing to its relatively good 
connectivity to other parts of India and an active pursuit of industrial policy, and fiscal and 
regulatory incentives to attract industry to Uttarakhand. The relative importance of tourism and 
industry to the economy are reflected in the gross domestic product (GDP) indicators which 
show that during the period 1999–2004, services (including tourism) accounted for over 40% of 
the state’s GDP; industry accounted for 26% and agriculture 34%. While the current contribution 
of agriculture to the state’s economy has been larger than that of industry, the annual growth 
rates of industry have been much higher than the agricultural growth rates.   
 
4.  Within this context, the urban centers of Uttarakhand play an increasingly important role 
in the state’s economic transformation. The evidence shows that cities and towns in the plains in 
southern  Uttarakhand  are  rapidly  becoming  the  locations  of  industry.  Following  the 
announcement of the industrial incentive policy, a large number of industrial units are in the 
process of setting, and two large-scale industrial estates have already been set up in the two 
major cities of the state. Moreover, many towns (both in the plains and the hills) are major 
tourist destinations, or are gateways to other tourism destinations, and so experience significant 
seasonal population increases. Apart from the towns in the plains, a large numbers of hill towns 
have a special character due to their religious and leisure tourism attractions. In 28 hill towns, 
annual tourist numbers grew by 17.8% during 2004–2005. The prospects for the growth of 
industry  and  tourism  in  Uttarakhand  are  therefore  contingent  upon  the  availability  of 
infrastructure and services which will support this economic growth and cater to the needs of a 
rapidly growing population in urban centers. However, the potential role that urban areas can 
play in Uttarakhand’s development is constrained by limited urban infrastructure and services.

2   
B.  Issues and Opportunities 
1.  Inadequate Urban Infrastructure and Services 
5.  An  assessment  of  urban  infrastructure  and  services  conditions  indicates  that 
infrastructure  and  services,  including  water  supply,  sanitation,  drainage,  solid-waste 
management, and urban transport and roads, are inadequate in urban areas. About 80% of the 
population has access to water supply, with about 78% with house connection and the balance 
drawing water from public standpipes. Service levels are poor, with water available in the pipes 
2–4 hours per day. While the state enjoys abundant water resources, the supply situation in hilly 
towns away from perennial rivers is critical, especially during the dry season; water supply costs 
are also too high as additional pumping is involved.  
 
6.  Only 20 towns have a centralized piped sewer system with coverage levels ranging 
between 30% and 75%. Of these towns served by piped sewers, only two have a sewerage 
treatment facility. Most waste water is co-disposed with storm water and thence into natural 
water courses, presenting severe environmental and health risk. Less than 50% of the solid 
waste generated is collected. The solid waste collected is generally disposed to open land, 
drains, and hill slopes in the absence of sanitary landfill sites. Solid-waste equipment and 
vehicles are inadequate. The problem is compounded during the tourist season when the 
amount of solid waste significantly increases.   
 
 7.  Urban roads are in poor condition; road networks and parking spaces are insufficient to 
meet the demands of current and future traffic volumes, given that traffic volumes have doubled 
in the last 10 years and are projected to do so again in the next 10 years. Narrow roads, 
coupled with poor traffic management, lead to congestion with subsequent inefficiency in urban 
mobility, air pollution, and risk to public safety. Due to favorable topography, the incidence of 
flooding is generally minimal, with the exception of some towns which have localized problems.  
 
2.  Urban Governance, Management, Service Delivery, and Finance 
8.  Urban Governance, Management, and Service Delivery. The low performance in 
infrastructure development and service delivery in the urban centers of Uttarakhand largely 
stems  from  inadequate  urban  institutional,  financial,  and  service-delivery  frameworks  and 
capacities. Primary responsibility for providing urban infrastructure and services (except for 
water supply and sewerage), including on-site sanitation, solid-waste management, drainage, 
road maintenance, street lighting, and slum improvement, lies with urban local bodies (ULBs). 
However, ULBs cannot perform their duties effectively as they lack required organizational 
capacities  and  operational  and  management  skills.  More  importantly,  financial  resources 
obtained through urban-based taxes and user charges are insufficient to fund the tasks of urban 
service delivery. 
 
9.  Water supply and sewerage (WSS) service provision is the responsibility of state water 
utilities, i.e., Uttarakhand Pey Jal Nigam (UPJN) for capital works and Uttarakhand Jal Sansthan 
(UJS)  for  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M),  which  operate  under  the  Drinking  Water 
Department (DDW). The issues contributing to the poor performance in WSS service delivery 
are (i) overlapping functioning of the two utilities, despite their intended distinct mandates; (ii) 
lack  of  separation  of  policy,  regulation,  and  service  delivery;  (iii)  lack  of  separation  of 
organization and finances of rural and urban water supply; and (iv) inadequate inclusion of 
ULBs and UJS in planning of water supply programs by UPJN (i.e, a supply-driven approach). 
The sustainability of WSS is further compromised by operational inefficiencies and inadequate 
tariffs. Unaccounted-for water is reported to be 30–50%, but is likely to be considerably higher. 
Metering  is  nonexistent  for  domestic  users.  There  is  need  for  (i)  a  higher  degree  of 
accountability, (ii) clear division of labor between UPJN and UJS, (iii) ring-fencing of urban 
WSS, (iv) improving capacities and skills in utilities, (v) rationalizing user charges, and (vi) an 
incentive structure to improve WSS service delivery.

3
10.  Urban and Municipal Finance. ULBs largely depend on grants and aid from the state to 
finance establishment and development expenditures. Currently, ULBs generate an average of 
26% and UJS generates 35% of their total revenues. Despite the high levels of state support, in 
many cases the total income is not sufficient to meet the salary and establishment costs. The 
current  revenue  base is  low,  and  there  are no  matching  sources of  funds  for  some  ULB 
functions (such as road maintenance). Property tax, a major source of local revenue, falls short 
of its full potential due to inadequate assessment, incomplete coverage of the tax net, and low 
collection efficiencies. In addition, the task of meeting the service needs of a large seasonal 
tourist population places an additional financial burden on ULBs. ULBs currently do not have 
credible  accounting  and  financial  reporting  systems  to  efficiently  manage  their  resources, 
although steps are being taken to remedy this.  
 
11.  Private Sector Participation (PSP). The Uttarakhand government has achieved some 
good  practices  in  PSP  through  build-operate-transfer  arrangements  for  the  Interstate  Bus 
Terminal at Dehradun owing to the potential of buoyant and rapidly increasing user fees for the 
bus  terminal.  However,  this  does  not  appear  to  be  readily  applicable  to  all  other  urban 
subsectors. The experience with PSP in other urban subsectors is limited only to short-term 
service  contracts  for  primary  collection  of  solid  waste  through  combining  community 
participation (through mahalla-neighborhood committees) with PSP. PSP on a larger scale is 
constrained by (i) inadequate cost recovery, (ii) low levels of institutional capacity to regulate 
and manage participation of the private sector, (iii) challenges posed by the state’s terrain, and 
(iv) the consequent reluctance by the private sector to take the perceived distribution-end risks 
associated with urban infrastructure. However, getting the private sector to take on responsibility 
for design, construction, and operation through design-build-operate or a performance-based 
deferred payment system contract is feasible, as revenue risks are borne by the public sector 
under such arrangements. The best value for this kind of public-private partnership (PPP) is to 
be gained from injecting the managerial and technical skills and efficiencies of the private sector 
into urban infrastructure development and service delivery. 
  
12.  Uttarakhand  Government’s  Urban  Reform  Orientation.  Notwithstanding  the 
inadequate  urban  institutional  and  financial  frameworks,  the  Uttarakhand  government  has 
implemented  a  number  of  sector  reform  initiatives,  demonstrating  its  reform  orientation. 
Significant among these initiatives are (i) the preparation of a Municipal Bill which provides for 
greater devolution to, and empowerment of, ULBs in line with the 74th Constitution Amendment 
Act (CAA); (ii) constitution of the Second State Finance Commission to strengthen state–urban 
local body relationships; (iii) repeal of the Urban Land Ceiling Act and reform of the Rent Control 
Act, both of which will enable land and housing markets to work more efficiently; (iv) a wide 
range of e-governance and information technology tools for use by ULBs to enhance good 
governance practices and improve urban planning, management capacities, property taxation, 
and the interface with the public; and (v) issuance of a government order to introduce double-
entry accrual accounting. More importantly, in May 2007, under the Jawaharlal Nehru National 
Urban Renewal Mission (JNNURM), the Uttarakhand government and its three major cities of 
Dehradun, Haridwar, and Nainital, signed a memorandum of agreement with the Ministry of 
Urban Development, demonstrating their commitment to a wide range of state- and local-level 
urban  reforms.  These  commitments  include  (i)  empowering  and  strengthening  ULBs,  (ii) 
improving financial management and accounting of ULBs and utilities, (iii) increasing revenues 
through property tax reform and rationalization of user charges, and (iv) restructuring utilities 
and incorporating private-sector efficiencies and accountabilities into service delivery.  
   
3.  External Assistance and Lessons Learned 
13.  External Assistance. To date, Uttarakhand has not received any significant external 
assistance  for  urban  development.  Limited  capacity-building  support  has  previously  been

4   
provided  by  other  donors,  including  the  United  Nations  Development  Programme  (UNDP). 
Currently the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) is supporting an 
initiative to develop e-governance at the state and ULB levels through its Financial Institution 
Reform  and  Expansion  program.1  Also  related  to,  or  impacting  on,  the  urban  sector  in 
Uttarakhand are ADB’s loan for the state roads project2 and the World Bank assistance for the 
rural water supply and sanitation program.3  
  
14.  The proposed Investment Program will be the first ADB urban-sector lending assistance 
in Uttarakhand. ADB has provided 31 technical assistance grants totaling $17.0 million to India’s 
urban sector since 1993, and has approved loans for 12 projects totaling $2.9 billion. The 
strategic thrust of ADB’s assistance has been poverty reduction through shared growth, social 
development, and good governance. These objectives have been translated into actions, mostly 
by integrated urban infrastructure and services projects. Recently, growing interstate disparities 
in India have become a concern for ADB and the Government in the context of the common 
core  objectives  of  redressing  regional  imbalances  and  inclusive  growth.  ADB  made  a 
commitment to diversify its operations to the northern states. Uttarakhand has been identified as 
one  of  the  geographic  areas  of  priority  for  ADB  assistance.  ADB  has  provided  a  project 
preparatory TA to support the Uttarakhand government’s efforts for preparing this Investment 
Program. ADB has also approved recently a component bridging TA4 to enhance the project 
preparedness and capacity of executing and implementing agencies to manage and implement 
the proposed Investment Program. The details of external support to India’s urban sector are in 
Appendix 2.  
 
15.  Lessons Learned. ADB’s past experience in the urban sector in India reveals the issues 
of  (i)  the  inherently  complex  nature  of  urban  development  projects  which  require  great 
coordination among concerned agencies and strong project management and implementation 
capacities; (ii) delays in project implementation, especially during project start up, and (iii) 
sustainability of project assets. The experience suggests that advance support for building 
capacities for project management and implementation has the potential to avoid start-up delays 
and increase effective project implementation. The experience also implies that greater care is 
needed to ensure sustainability through (i) greater involvement and ownership of stakeholders 
during project design; (ii) phasing urban reforms commensurate with institutional capacities over 
realistic periods; (iii) long-term capacity development of ULBs and other urban service providers 
in planning, managing, and financing urban infrastructure and services; and (iv) introducing 
incentive and greater accountability structures into urban service-delivery systems. All these 
lessons have been incorporated into the design of the Investment Program.

The importance of Uttarakhand and its urban sector in the national scene has been further 
highlighted by the inclusion of Dehradun, Haridwar, and Nainital in a list of 63 cities eligible for

development. A fundamental point of reference in these plans is the 74th CAA, which promotes 
devolution of responsibility to, and empowerment of, ULBs so that they can play a pivotal role in

to sustainable urban development through reform-linked investments. The JNNURM aims to 
fast-track infrastructure investments in 63 cities, subject to their commitment to a range of 
reforms. The envisaged reforms focus on decentralized governance and municipal finance. The 
JNNURM also advocates (i) balancing asset creation with maintenance, (ii) PSP in service 
delivery, and (iii) financially sustainable service providers for WSS. 
 
18.  At the state level, the Uttarakhand government’s urban policy objectives reiterate those 
of the central government, combining high-growth strategies with poverty reduction, building on 
areas  of  strategic  importance,  including  urban  infrastructure  and  institutional  development. 
Being a new state, Uttarakhand does not have a history of urban focus; however, budget 
allocations of recent years reflect an increasing outlay on urban infrastructure, with capital 
expenditure increasing from 33% in 2003–2004 to 44% in 2005–2006. More importantly, the 
Uttarakhand  government’s  initiation  of  a  number  of  urban  reforms,  and  the  signing  of  a 
memorandum of understanding with the Government to implement further reforms under the 
JNNURM, amply establishes the Uttarakhand government’s commitment not only to developing 
physical infrastructure assets but also to sustainable urban service delivery.  
 
19.  Vision. The Uttarakhand Urban Sector Road Map has been guided by the above urban 
policy framework. The road map aims to provide critically needed urban infrastructure and 
services, leading to a better quality of life for the estimated 4.05 million people projected to be 
living in the 31 program towns by 2018. It combines capital investments with support to the 
Uttarakhand government’s urban reform agenda to ensure sustainable outcomes. The road map 
targets selected urban centers which will lead industrial and tourism growth while contributing to 
the reduction of poverty. The Investment Program to be financed by ADB will meet the priority 
investment and capacity development needs and pave the way to attainment of the vision set 
out for the Uttarakhand urban areas. The road map is presented as Schedule 1 to the Financing 
Framework Agreement (FFA). 
 
20.  Ten-Year Infrastructure Investment Plan. It is estimated that about $1.5 billion is 
required in the next 10 years to meet the infrastructure requirements of about 31 towns in 
Uttarakhand. Investments include water supply, sewerage, drainage, solid-waste management, 
roads  and  transport,  slum  improvement,  and  urban  renewal.  The  10-year  infrastructure 
investment plan is based on (i) central and state government policy, plans, and targets for 
infrastructure; (ii) city development plans for three cities, and town reports for six representative 
towns, providing in-depth demographic, spatial, infrastructure, and institutional analyses and city 
investment  plans;  (iii)  city  growth  strategies  and  land-use  master  plans;  (iv)  available 
infrastructure  master  plans;  (v)  consultations  with  stakeholders;  (vi)  surveys  profiling 
infrastructure  deficiencies  and  gaps  in  service  performances;  and  (vii)  financing  needs  for 
infrastructure over the next 10 years. It is envisaged that funding requirements for the 10-year 
plan will be met by different sources, e.g., the state budget, the JNNURM, and the Urban 
Infrastructure  Development  Scheme  for  Small  and  Medium  Towns.  A  large  portion  of  the 
funding requirement is expected to be met by the JNNURM. The proposed Investment Program 
forms a part of the 10-year investment plan.  
 
21.  Urban Reform Agenda. In parallel with improving urban infrastructure, the Uttarakhand 
government under its road map sets a vision for enhancing urban governance, finance, and

6   
service  delivery  in  line  with  its  agreement  to  implement  JNNURM  reforms.  The  urban 
governance,  finance,  and  service-delivery  improvement  action  plan,  which  is  presented  in 
Appendix 3, is grouped into three major interrelated areas. The first major area of reform is 
promoting  decentralized  urban  governance  through  the  gradual  empowerment  and 
enhancement of the capacities of ULBs in urban planning and management.   
 
22.  The second area of reform is the restructuring of utilities for efficient, accountable, and 
financially  sustainable  WSS  service  provision  within  the  decentralization  framework.  This 
involves (i) the separation of policy, regulation, and service delivery at the state level, starting 
with a small regulatory unit within the Uttarakhand government; (ii) bringing clarity to the current 
confusing roles of UPJN and UJS; (iii) separating urban and rural water supply by ring-fencing 
of urban WSS with regard to labor, financing, and accounting; (iv) developing a participatory and 
professional governance structure within UPJN and UJS with greater ULB representation and 
co-opting of experts; and (v) injecting an accountability and incentive mechanism through a 
performance-based contractual relationship among UJS as service provider, ULBs as ultimate 
owners, and the state (provider of grant and subsidies), with predefined targets for improvement 
in unaccounted-for water, billing, the collection of (and gradual increase in) user charges, and 
reducing subsidies. In the medium term, as devolution progresses with stronger ULBs, this 
tripartite contractual relationship will evolve into a contract between ULBs and UJS, with ULBs 
having full oversight of the WSS delivered by service provider (UJS and/or the private sector). 
Appendix 4 describes in detail the improvements for sustainable and accountable WSS.  
 
23.  The third area of reform relates to improving revenues and financial management. This 
involves rationalization of user charges to gradually recover the full operation and maintenance 
costs through the gradual increase in water tariffs and implementing (i) a volumetric water 
charge, (ii) a sewerage surcharge on the water bill, and (iii) a solid-waste management charge. 
The  revenue  generation  reforms  also  include  increasing  property  tax  revenues  through 
increasing tax coverage, changing the method of tax assessment and improving tax collection 
efficiencies. Moreover, reforms envisage gradual development of new sources of revenue for 
the maintenance of urban roads. These are supported by financial management reforms for the 
adoption of accrual-based double-entry accounting in ULBs and utilities, and the introduction of 
e-governance systems. The Uttarakhand government recognizes that these reforms also set the 
stage for increased PSP in urban infrastructure provision.   
     
III.  THE PROPOSED INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
A.  Impact and Outcome  
 
24.  The anticipated impact of the Investment Program is an improved quality of life for the 
urban residents of Uttarakhand. The expected outcome of the Investment Program is increased 
access to better quality urban infrastructure and services by the 3.8 million people projected to 
be living within the 31 Program towns by 2016. It is also expected that the Investment Program 
will enhance the quality of services and experience enjoyed by more than 8 million tourists and 
pilgrims who visit the Program towns annually.   
 
B.  Outputs 
 
25.  To achieve the intended impact and outcomes, the Investment Program comprises two 
major  interrelated  areas  of  interventions.  Part  A  covers  urban  infrastructure  and  services 
improvements including the rehabilitation, improvement, and expansion of (i) water supply, (ii) 
sewerage and sanitation, (iii) solid-waste management, (iv) urban transportation and roads, and 
(v) slum upgrading. Part B covers (i) Investment Program management support, and (ii) a 
comprehensive  program  of  capacity  development  to  assist  in  the  attainment  of  the  urban

7
governance,  finance,  and  service-delivery  improvement  action  plan  and  to  enhance  the 
capacities of the urban service providers, including ULBs. 
 
1.  Part A: Urban Infrastructure and Services Improvements  
26.  Water Supply. Investments are aimed at improving both the quantity and quality of 
water  supply  to  national  and state  standards  through  (i)  improving  information on  existing 
networks; (ii) reducing unaccounted-for water through leak detection, system rehabilitation and 
repair,  and  reducing  illegal  connections;  (iii)  system  rationalization  and  optimization  (e.g., 
replacement of bunched connections); (iv) provision of bulk and consumer meters and other 
system  improvements;  and  (v)  where  necessary,  augmenting  supplies  and  extending 
distribution  networks.  This  will  enable  83%  coverage  to  be  achieved  by  the  end  of  the 
Investment Program period of 2016, with a majority of households receiving potable water 24 
hours  a  day.  These  investments  will  be  accompanied  by  civic  awareness  campaigns  and 
capacity development to support WSS reforms for sustainable service delivery under Part B. 
 
27.  Wastewater  Management.  Investments  are  aimed  at  improving  the  environmental 
quality of urban areas and receiving water bodies, with a consequent impact on public health. 
Improvements are targeted, by end of 2016, at providing collection and treatment of sewage by 
appropriate technology and extending service coverage to an average of 60% with 50–90% in 
the  larger  towns  and  30-50%  in  medium-size  towns.  In  smaller  towns,  on-site  sanitation 
improvements will generally be undertaken. The sewer networks will mostly cover the town core 
area; on the outskirts of towns, where extending networks would not be economical due to 
scattered  habitation  or  geographical  constraints,  on-site  sanitation  will  be  provided.  The 
technology options will follow the particular geographical and climatic features of the town as 
well  as  quantity  of  sewage  load.  Investments  will  be  accompanied  by  public  awareness 
campaigns and capacity development to ensure system sustainability under Part B. 
  
28.  Solid-Waste Management. Investments are aimed at improving public health and the 
environmental quality of Program towns and adjacent open land and water bodies through 
increasing solid-waste collection coverage from 50% to 72%, and supporting sound solid-waste 
disposal methods. Improvements will be directed at (i) segregation of solid waste at household 
level and handling and management improvements at ward and town levels with an emphasis 
on waste minimization, (ii) provision of solid-waste collection and transportation equipment, and 
(iii) construction of sanitary landfill sites in accordance with the Government’s Municipal Solid 
Waste  Management  and  Handling  Rules,  2000.  These  will  build  on  a  state  solid-waste 
management strategy and action plan, and will be supported by capacity development of ULBs 
under Part B.    
 
29.  Urban  Transport  and  Roads.  Interventions will  aim  at improving  traffic conditions, 
reducing journey times, and improving the safety of all users, particularly the most vulnerable 
(pedestrians,  cyclists,  and  motorcyclists),  through  a  combination  of  investments.  These 
investments  will  generally  focus  on  major  roads  and  will  include  (i)  road  widening  and 
strengthening to create greater road capacity, thus relieving congestion and easing traffic flows; 
(ii) car parking restrictions and the provision of multistory car parks and bus and truck terminals, 
where possible through PSP, to enhance passenger convenience and increase road space; (iii) 
provision of pedestrian subways and footpaths to improve pedestrian movement and safety; (iv) 
traffic management improvements; and (v) street lighting for improved traffic and pedestrian 
safety. 
 
30.  Slum Improvement. Interventions will include the provision of bulk water supply and 
sewerage mains at the entry to slum areas, and improvements to solid-waste management, 
access roads, street lighting, and drainage in poor communities and slums, which accommodate 
around 300,000 poor people, accounting for about half of the slum population in the state. The

8   
selection, approach, and strategic responses to the broader issues of slum population and poor 
communities will be based on a state slum upgrading strategy to be developed at the outset of 
the Investment Program under part B. A demand-led approach to developing community-level 
infrastructure  and  services  will  be  followed.  Slum  upgrading  subprojects  will  be  generated 
through a participatory planning process by communities with the assistance of community-
based organizations and nongovernment organizations (NGOs) as applicable. Support will be 
provided to ULBs and communities for effective joint functioning in developing, implementing, 
and sustaining community-based urban upgrading schemes. The component will benefit from, 
and  build  on,  existing  community-based  organizations’  efforts  and  the  Uttarakhand 
government’s poverty reduction schemes. 
 
2.  Part  B:  Capacity  Development  and  Investment  Program  Management 
Support 
31.  Capacity  Development.  Assistance  will  support  the  attainment  of  the  Uttarakhand 
government’s urban governance, finance, and service-delivery improvement action plan and 
related institutional development needs. Support will be provided to the state, ULBs, and utilities 
in (i) furthering decentralized urban governance, (ii) sustainable WSS service delivery, and (iii) 
urban  and  municipal  finance  reforms,  including  PSP  in  urban  infrastructure  and  service 
provision.  
 
32.  Support  for  decentralized  urban  governance  will  prepare  ULBs  for  their  increased 
responsibilities under the Uttarakhand government’s devolution policy. Feasible action plans will 
be  developed  to  gradually  devolve  functions  to  ULBs,  and  commensurate  organizational 
development. Priority will be given to enhancing the capacities of ULBs in asset management 
and  O&M  of  services  for  which  they  are  currently  responsible,  such  as  solid-waste 
management.  
 
33.  The capacity-development component will support the Uttarakhand government’s road 
map for efficient, financially sustainable, and accountable WSS service delivery. Expert inputs 
will be provided to conduct institutional surveys and develop and assist implementing detailed 
proposals and action plans in consultation with stakeholders to (i) separate regulation and 
service-delivery functions; (ii) remove the overlaps in the functioning of UPJN and UJS; (iii) 
develop measures for involvement of ULBs in planning and provision of WSS; (iv) establish 
clear  accountabilities  between  service  provider,  ULBs,  and  the  state;  and  (v)  introduce 
improvements into the governance structure and the organizational and operational systems of 
UJS, including in asset management, financial management systems, and staff skills.  
 
34.  This  component  will  also  support  the  improvement  of  local  revenues  and  financial 
management. Assistance will be given in the restructuring of water tariffs to consumption-based 
volumetric tariffs, introduction of a sewerage surcharge and solid-waste management charge, 
and achievement of the cost-recovery targets. Assistance will also be directed at increasing 
property tax revenues through increasing tax coverage, revising the method of tax assessment, 
and improving tax collection efficiencies. Moreover, the component will assist ULBs and water 
utilities  to  introduce  and  implement  accrual-based  double-entry  accounting,  including 
preparation of manuals, installation of computerized systems, and training of staff of utilities and 
ULBs.   
 
35.  Another  area  of  assistance  under  this  component  will  be  promoting  PSP  in  urban 
infrastructure development in accordance with Uttarakhand government policy. Support will be 
provided to (i) create an enabling framework, (ii) transfer knowledge and skills and strengthen 
capacities in planning and managing PSP, and (iii) identify suitable components and develop 
PPP schemes.

future investments. A slum strategy study will develop (i) slum mapping; (ii) different typology of

37.  Investment  Program  Management.  This  component  supports  funding  the  costs  of 
Investment Program management and implementation, including incremental administration and 
operations associated with the investment program management unit (IPMU) in the Urban 
Development Department (UDD), the IPIUs in UPJN, the Public Works Department (PWD), and 
ULBs, and provision of equipment, logistics, and consulting services to assist the IPMU and 
IPIUs. 
 
38.  Consultancy support will also include (i) on-the-job training to build the capacity of the 
executing and implementing agencies in project management and implementation (technical, 
environmental and social aspects, and planning and monitoring); and (ii) assistance to ULBs 
and utilities for effective O&M of the Investment Program assets.  
 
39.  This  component  will  also  include  a  program  of  community  participation  and  civic 
awareness activities. An area of focus will be awareness raising on the public’s role in, and 
responsibility  for,  good  environmental  practices  in  solid-waste  management.  Activities  will 
include  promoting  participation  of  urban  residents  (including  women  and  the  poor)  in  the 
Program,  e.g.,  subproject  preparation,  construction,  and  monitoring  activities.  Services  of 
NGOs, training, and equipment will be provided to help carry out these activities. 
  
C.  Important Features 
40.  Planned  and  Integrated  Approach  to  City  Development.  The  design  of  the 
Investment Program follows a planned approach. The identification of the long-term investment 
requirements and the design of the Investment Program and subprojects are based on growth 
strategies, city development and land-use plans, town development reports, and infrastructure 
master plans. The Investment Program is also based on the principle of the integrated provision 
of various urban infrastructure and services to maximize the benefits from individual sector 
improvements.  
 
41.  Support to Reforms for Urban Governance, Finance, Service Delivery, and Private 
Sector Participation. An important feature of the Investment Program is its support to the 
Uttarakhand government’s urban reform action plan for efficient, sustainable, inclusive, and 
accountable service delivery. This is to be achieved through supporting (i) the decentralization 
agenda  of  the  Uttarakhand  government  and  strengthening  the  capacities  of  ULBs;  (ii) 
development  of  efficient,  accountable,  and  sustainable  service  delivery;  and  (iii)  creating 
sustainable sources of revenue through rationalization of service charges and taxes.  
 
42.  It is envisaged that the above reforms will also significantly contribute to creating an 
enabling environment for PSP. In addition, dedicated efforts will be made to develop specific 
PPP packages under the Investment Program. Both during the project preparatory technical 
assistance and during loan fact-finding, extensive assessment and dialogue with government 
and  private-sector  representatives  was  conducted  on  viable  options  for  PSP  in  urban 
infrastructure development in Uttarakhand. In addition to short-term service contracts, there are 
particular opportunities for PPP arrangements to bring service efficiencies in parking facilities, 
solid-waste  management,  water  supply,  and  wastewater  management.  The  Uttarakhand

10   
government has indicated its interest in extending the defect liability period in its engineering 
procurement contracts from the current 1 year to 5 years. This type of arrangement would 
ensure that private operators take responsibility for the performance of their technology and 
management. Appropriate PPP packages will be further developed for suitable subprojects at 
the outset of the Investment Program (Supplementary Appendix A) in coordination with ADB’s 
ongoing TA project.5  
 
43.  Inclusive Urban Growth. The Investment Program will include measures for inclusive 
urban development through (i) supporting the development of a statewide slum strategy to 
integrate the urban poor into urban development, (ii) targeted interventions in the form of a slum 
upgrading component which will address the basic needs of urban poor communities building on 
a state slum strategy, and (iii) address the affordability constraints of the poor through measures 
such as lifeline tariffs and free service connections for poor people.  
 
44.  Bridging Technical Assistance. The Investment Program is supported by a grant-
funded bridging TA based on the experience of ADB with previous urban sector projects in India 
which show significant delay in commencement of actual fieldwork after the loan becomes 
effective. The component bridging TA (see footnote 4) therefore aims to avoid start-up delays by 
enhancing the preparedness of the executing and implementing agencies to implement the 
forthcoming Investment Program. The component bridging TA, which commenced in June 2007, 
will assist UDD, as the Executing Agency (EA) , with (i) familiarizing itself with ADB procedures, 
(ii) the preparation of various documents (such as standard bidding documents), (iii) undertaking 
advance  action  for  recruitment  of  program  management  consultants,  and  (iv)  conducting 
surveys and mapping to accelerate detailed design of first tranche subprojects.  
  
45.  Multitranche  Financing  Facility.  The  Investment  Program  will  be  an  MFF.  The 
rationale for designing the Investment Program as an MFF is derived from the broad agenda of 
the road map, which involves provision of urban infrastructure and services in around 31 cities 
and  towns  with  varying  levels  of  needs  and  capacities.  The  MFF  will  enable  flexibility  in 
investment decisions based on the needs and constraints of each city within a framework 
instead  of  an  upfront  and  precise  definition  of  investments  as  required  in  a  conventional 
assistance modality. It will allow the implementation to be based on the readiness of individual 
subprojects and cities, as under the MFF funds will be made available to the state in a phased 
manner subject to readiness of appropriate subprojects. The use of an MFF will enable ADB 
and the Uttarakhand government to develop a long-term partnership for developing the urban 
areas of Uttarakhand in a sustainable manner. It will allow long-term engagement for building 
the capacities of urban institutions and reform actions within a realistic time frame. Finally, the 
use of an MFF will provide flexibility to match various funding sources available to the central 
and state governments.

E.  Implementation Arrangements  
1.  Investment Program Management  
49.  The EA for the Investment Program will be the Uttarakhand government’s UDD. An 
IPMU has already been established in UDD to manage and monitor the implementation of the 
Investment Program, and provide policy direction. The IPMU is envisaged to be registered 
under the Societies Registration Act The registration of the IPMU as a society will enable (i)

day-to-day business and decision making, (ii) efficient disbursement and prompt payment of 
funds to contractors and suppliers, and (iii) engagement of qualified staff and outsourcing the 
services of professionals as needed. The IPMU will have a charter or constitution that will be 
satisfactory to ADB.

4.  Implementation Schedule of the Investment Program  
58.  The proposed Investment Program will be implemented over a period of 8 years (2008–
2016) in four tranches with preparation of first tranche subprojects commencing in 2007 and 
works in 2008. The sequencing of tranches has been based on a number of principles, including 
(i) readiness of subprojects in terms of institutional capacities and safeguard compliance, e.g., 
land acquisition and resettlement and environmental aspects; (ii) relative investment priorities 
under the Investment Program, which ranks the subprojects for efficiency improvements of 
existing  utility  systems  and  capacity  development  of  service  providers  higher  than  system 
expansions; and (iii) size, growth rates, and economic potential of towns which together indicate 
the relative level of priority for investments.  
 
59.   In line with the above principles, first tranche subprojects will focus on optimization and 
rehabilitation of water supply and sewerage systems, including reduction of leakages and bulk 
and individual water metering in the three rapidly growing larger towns (Dehradun, Haridwar, 
and Nainital) and also the sewerage and sewage treatment facilities for part of Dehradun. These 
investments do not involve land acquisition, resettlement, or any major social and environmental 
issues. The first tranche will also fund the capacity-development component for all Program 
towns to support the implementation of the urban governance, finance, and service-delivery 
improvement action plan (including detailed studies and plans, cost-recovery based tariffs, and 
improved accounting) and several key studies comprising a solid-waste management strategy 
and action plan, slum improvement action plan, and civic awareness program for community-
level solid-waste management improvement. 
 
60.  The  second  tranche  will  cover  most  of  the  balance  of  works  in  water  supply  and 
sewerage in the priority towns, including system rehabilitation and the expansion of the water 
supply and sewerage systems based on master plans available or prepared under the first 
tranche. In addition, the tranche will cover slum upgrading in the rapidly growing largest towns 
based on a slum upgrading strategy and action plan developed under the first tranche.  
 
61.  The  third  tranche  will  support  water  supply  and  sewerage  subprojects  in  the  more 
remote  hilly  towns  where  infrastructure  and  service  expansion  based  on  master  plans  is 
required, in particular to serve the needs of the expanding tourism industry and the prevention 
of water pollution in rivers by creating sewerage and sewage-treatment facilities in towns which 
are located on the banks of major rivers.  
 
62.  The fourth tranche will include any subprojects which require a long lead-in period due to 
the need for land acquisition or resettlement. The fourth tranche, therefore, based on the solid-
waste  management  strategy  and  action  plan,  the  collection  and  disposal  efficiency 
improvements, and the acquisition of land by the Uttarakhand government, will include solid-
waste management improvements including sanitary landfill site development in all Program 
towns (excluding Dehradun, Nainital, and part of Haridwar, which will be undertaken by the 
JNNURM). The fourth tranche will also include road and transport subprojects which will only be 
undertaken  after  the  construction  of  road-cutting  subprojects  such  as  water  supply  and 
sewerage.

A.  Economic Analysis 
81.  The economic analysis has reviewed the Investment Program’s (i) economic rationale 
for government intervention, (ii) goals, (iii) sector development plans, (iv) associated economic 
policies, (v) economic risks, (vi) Uttarakhand government’s capacity, (vii) fiscal impact, (viii) 
Uttarakhand  government’s  commitment,  (ix)  coordination  of  foreign  aid,  and  (x)  conditions 
attached to the loan. The economic rationale for government intervention is justified, since the 
Investment Program supports all basic public services which are characterized by monopolistic 
conditions,  externality  management,  and  impacts  on  income  distribution.  The  goals  of  the 
program  are  consistent  with  the  Government’s  goals  of  redressing  regional  imbalances, 
enhancing economic growth, and reducing poverty in Uttarakhand as reflected in the 10th Five-

19
Year Plan, the Approach Paper for the 11th Five-Year Plan, and other policy documents. The 
strategy  of  the  Investment  Program,  which  combines  physical  investments  with  capacity 
development  to  support  urban  institutional  and  financial  reforms,  fully  conform  with  the 
Government’s  policy  of  linking  funds  for  capital  investment  to  improved  institutional 
performances. 
  
82.  The scope of investments under the Program is based on extensive consultations and 
reflects  the  priorities  of  all  stakeholders.  The  investments  are  also  based  on  the  city 
development  plans  prepared  for  the  three  first-tranche  cities,  city  growth  strategies  for  all 
program cities, and available infrastructure master plans providing a systematic and coordinated 
framework for long-term investments and multiple funding sources. All the subprojects for which 
economic analysis was undertaken under the Investment Program demonstrate an economic 
internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  above  12%,  or  meet  the  economic  selection  criteria  for  the 
Investment Program. The economic analysis is presented in Supplementary Appendix D. 
  
B.  Financial Management Assessment and Financial Analysis 
83.  The financial management assessment revealed that both UJS and ULBs did not have 
adequate operational income to meet operational expenses. This calls for institutional reform to 
improve  their  financial  base,  including  (i)  increasing  the  property  tax  base,  reassessment, 
mapping,  and  computerized  database;  (ii)  a  gradual  increase  in  user  charges;  and  (iii) 
improvements  in  collection  efficiency.  To  achieve  these  reforms,  an  indicative  financial 
improvement action plan agreed by the Uttarakhand government is shown in the financial 
analysis (Appendix 9), which provides specific figures for the introduction of new user charges, 
tariff increases, target service coverages, and tariff collection efficiency. 
 
84.  UPJN and UJS have already adopted accrual-based double-entry accounting, prepared 
the manual, and commenced using the new system in some areas, in addition to computerizing 
their  operations,  including  tariff  collection.  However,  other  state  agencies  and  ULBs  are 
currently using cash-basis accounting. This does not provide an accurate status of agencies 
with regard to their assets, including receivables and liabilities. Further, asset receding, physical 
verification of assets, and reconciliation with records are not kept current due to inadequate 
skills  of  staff  and  excess  workloads.  In  order  to  strengthen  the  capacity  for  financial 
management and work efficiency, accountants from relevant state departments, ULBs, UPJN, 
and UJS, in addition to the IPMU and IPIUs, will be trained in budgeting, financial information 
management and reporting, accrual-based double-entry accounting, and the use of information 
technology.  
 
85.  Financial sustainability and viability of the subprojects under the first tranche of the 
Investment Program was assessed in accordance with the Financial Management and Analysis 
of  Projects.8  For  revenue  generating  sectors—water  supply,  sewerage,  and  solid-waste 
management—incremental revenue and cost due to the subprojects are estimated on a with-
project and without-project basis. Tariff revisions for water supply, sewerage, and solid-waste 
management are required to meet the financial improvement action plan of achieving full O&M 
cost recovery within the Investment Program implementation period. The financial internal rate 
of return (FIRR) for water supply subprojects ranges from 1.3% to 20.1%, for a sewerage 
subproject  it  is  7.3%,  and  for  solid-waste  management  subprojects  it  is  17.3%.  All  the 
subprojects have an estimated FIRR which is above the weighted average cost of capital 
(WACC) of 3.58%. Sensitivity analysis shows generally robust FIRRs, showing that the FIRRs 
are the most sensitive to the level of demand. In other words, an increase in coverage is critical 
to obtaining desirable returns on investment.

86.  Income poverty9 in Uttarakhand is estimated at over 33%. The urban population living in 
slums10 accounts for 17% of the total state urban population. About 43% of the slums are 
located on urban fringes and 53% are along drains.11 Urban poor people’s access to basic 
urban infrastructure and services is more limited. Only 71.4% of the slums are serviced by piped 
potable water, and only 42.8% of slum dwellers have access to proper sanitation facilities. This 
situation creates unfavorable environmental conditions for poor people and threatens public 
health. The Investment Program will have positive impacts on poor people. Safe drinking water 
is a basic need which a significant number of the poor in Uttarakhand do not have access to. 
The burden of water collection on vulnerable segments of the population (especially women) will 
be  reduced,  and  tariffs  will  be  set  to  ensure  that  poor  people  can  afford  drinking  water. 
Improvements in water supply, sewage, sanitation, and solid-waste management will lead to 
public health improvements, resulting in reductions in the burden of diseases, treatment costs, 
and productivity losses, the impacts of which are experienced by the poor in high degree. Slum 
upgrading subprojects are directly targeted at improving basic infrastructure in poor areas. The 
services  to  be  provided  under  this  component  are  described  in  para.  30.  The  expected 
incidental  benefits  are  economic  growth  and  direct  temporary  employment  of  the  poor  in 
construction work under the Investment Program. The summary poverty reduction and social 
strategy is in Appendix 10.  
 
D.  Social and Environmental Safeguards 
87.  Social Safeguards. The Investment Program will minimize resettlement impacts by 
prioritizing rehabilitation and optimization work within existing facilities. New construction is 
proposed on vacant government land where feasible. Tranche 1 subprojects will not require 
land acquisition, and show that the main resettlement impacts will be due to rehabilitation and 
laying of pipe networks, and these impacts are temporary. Draft short resettlement plans were 
prepared for tranche 1 subprojects in three towns (Supplementary Appendix E).12 Resettlement 
impacts are to be further minimized through careful subproject siting and alignment during 
detailed design and subproject implementation. To ensure compliance with Government and 
ADB policies and requirements on involuntary resettlement, a resettlement framework was 
prepared on the basis of the Government’s Land Acquisition Act, 1894 (LAA, amended in 1984) 
and the National Rehabilitation and Resettlement Policy, 2007 (NRRP); and ADB’s Policy on 
Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy  (1995).  The  resettlement  framework  will  guide  the 
implementation of subprojects, outlining the objectives, policy principles, procedures for land 
acquisition (if required), compensation, and other assistance measures for affected persons. A 
summary of the resettlement framework is in Appendix 11 and the full resettlement framework is 
in Supplementary Appendix F. Resettlement plans will be prepared for subprojects based on the 
resettlement framework. Subprojects with significant13 impacts require full resettlement plans, 
while subprojects with insignificant impacts will require short resettlement plans. Resettlement 
plans will ensure that socioeconomic conditions and the needs and priorities of vulnerable 
groups  are  identified,  and  that  the  process  of  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  does  not 
disadvantage vulnerable groups.

89.  Environmental  Safeguards.  The  Investment  Program  is  designed  to  improve 
environmental quality and living conditions in urban areas through the provision of basic urban 
services. Initial environmental examinations (IEEs) conducted for the Investment Program show 
that net subproject environmental benefits are positive and extensive, and include (i) reduced 
pollution of water resources due to discharge of untreated sewage and indiscriminate solid-
waste disposal from sewerage and sewage treatment, and municipal solid-waste management 
investments; (ii) increased availability of adequate potable water at appropriate pressure from 
water supply subprojects; (iii) better public health, particularly a reduction in waterborne and 
infectious diseases through water supply, sewerage and sewage treatment, and municipal solid-
waste management investments; (iv) improved aesthetics from the improvement of urban roads, 
sewerage and sewage treatment, and municipal solid-waste management works; (v) reduced 
exposure to suspended particulates and noise pollution; and (vi) increased pedestrian safety 
through urban roads and traffic management. Potential negative environmental impacts are 
mostly localized and temporary, and are mostly related to dust, noise, and access disruptions 
due  to  construction  activities  and  construction-related  waste  disposal.  These  impacts  can 
largely be avoided through proper subproject design (particularly in siting), or mitigated through 
proper mitigation measures and environmental management (Appendix 12 and Supplementary 
Appendix H).  
 
90.  Environmental  subproject  selection  guidelines  further  ensure  that  the  Investment 
Program will not have significant negative environmental impacts. Impacts that are potentially 
significant  and  permanent  in  nature  have  been  identified,  and  environmental  subproject 
selection guidelines will not allow subprojects with such impacts. To ensure compliance with 
Government and ADB policies, guidelines, and requirements, an environmental assessment 
and review framework to guide the implementation of future subprojects has been developed 
(Supplementary Appendix I).  
 
E.  Risks 
91.  The main risks are related to Program implementation performance and sustainability of 
investments. These include (i) slow Program implementation, which is a common feature of 
urban sector projects; (ii) lack of availability of land for locating assets such as pumping stations, 
reservoirs, and landfill sites for solid-waste management, and delays in obtaining land from 
government; and (iii) delayed implementation of urban reform action plan, reluctance in levying 
and collecting increased user charges, and inadequate public willingness to pay for the services 
which overall present a risk to sustainability.  
 
92.  The Investment Program addresses these risks through a number of measures. Risks 
for slow Program implementation will be mitigated by establishing the IPMU and IPIUs as 
efficient units with qualified staff supported by project management consultants. UDD as the EA 
has already appointed a qualified program director who has extensive experience in managing 
and implementing similar ADB-funded urban projects. In addition, ADB’s recently approved 
component  bridging  TA  for  Project  Implementation  and  Capacity  Building  Support  for 
Uttarakhand (see footnote 4) will provide support to give exposure to UDD and the IAs in ADB 
procedures and  guidance  in  recruitment  of  the  project  management  consultants,  and  help 
prepare the first tranche subprojects.

22   
93.  The  shortage  of  land  for  landfill  sites  will  be  addressed  by  introducing  innovative 
systems such as waste minimization at source, composting, and developing common landfill 
sites for clusters of towns. Delays in transferring appropriate land from government will be 
minimized by (i) appropriate sequencing of tranches which involve those subprojects requiring 
land, and (ii) taking actions sufficiently in advance to acquire land. The fact that the conversion 
of land use in Uttarakhand is through a well established procedure of seeking and obtaining 
permission from the Government is also expected to minimize delays.  
 
94.  Implementation of the urban governance, finance, and service-delivery improvement 
action plan will not present a great risk due to the reform-minded Uttarakhand government and 
the ownership of the state, ULBs, and utilities of the reform agenda under the JNNURM. Civic 
awareness  program  will  stimulate  demand  for,  and  increase  the  recognition  of,  the  value 
attached to improved services among urban residents. The Investment Program strategy of 
combining investments with capacity-development assistance will enable urban institutions to 
implement the action plan. These will be supported by ADB’s continued policy dialogue during 
implementation.  
 
V.  ASSURANCES 
95.  In addition to the standard assurances, following assurances from the Government and 
the Uttarakhand government are sought. These assurances will be incorporated in to the FFA 
as well as the individual loan and project agreements as applicable subject to any amendment 
to be mutually agreed by the Government and the Uttarakhand government. 
 
(i)  The Uttarakhand government will ensure that the Urban Governance, Finance, 
and Service Delivery Improvement Action Plan (Appendix 3) will be implemented 
in accordance with the time frame set in the action plan.  
(ii)  The  Government  will  make  available  to  the  Uttarakhand  government  the 
proceeds  of  the  financing  provided  by  ADB.  The  Uttarakhand  government 
commits to bear the foreign exchange risk for such proceeds of the financing 
provided by the Government.  
(iii)  The Government and the Uttarakhand government will ensure that sufficient 
counterpart funds are made available from their budget for each fiscal year, in a 
timely manner, for timely implementation of the Investment Program.  
(iv)  The Uttarakhand government will ensure that sufficient funds will be provided to 
meet  any  shortfall  between  the  cost  of  and  revenues  for  the  O&M  of  the 
infrastructure assets created under the Investment Program.  
(v)  The  Government  and  the  Uttarakhand  government  will  ensure  that  the 
Investment Program funds are utilized effectively and efficiently to implement the 
Investment Program and achieve its objectives. The EA will ensure compliance 
with the specific anticorruption and governance mitigation measures identified in 
paragraph 72 above.  
(vi)  The Uttarakhand government will ensure that contractual documents under any 
PPP modality are provided to ADB for prior review and approval in order to be 
used under the individual subprojects. 
(vii)  The Uttarakhand government will ensure that all land and right-of-way required 
for the Investment Program are made available in a timely manner, adequate 
compensation including resettlement assistance is provided prior to the award of 
relevant  civil  works  contracts,  and  involuntary  resettlement  is  carried  out  in 
accordance with the Resettlement Framework and Resettlement Plans agreed 
upon between the Government and ADB, the Government's NRRP (2007), and 
ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995). An RP will be prepared for each 
subproject involving land acquisition or resettlement and shall be submitted to

IMPROVEMENTS FOR SUSTAINABLE AND ACCOUNTABLE WATER  
AND SEWERAGE PROVISION  
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The Government of India, through the 74th Constitutional Amendment Act (CAA) and 
revised guidelines of the Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban Renewal Mission (JNNURM), has 
mandated  the  decentralization  of  key  urban  services,  including  urban  water  supply  and 
sewerage, to urban local bodies (ULBs). The JNNURM guidelines, taking into account varying 
levels of organizational and financial preparedness of the ULBs, stipulated that in JNNURM 
cities over a period of 7 years, all agencies that deliver urban services are either transferred to 
ULBs,  or  platforms  are  created  for  accountable  service  providers  within  the  decentralized 
framework. The present institutional structure of urban water supply and sewerage (WSS) in 
Uttarakhand  exists  at  state  level  and  is  managed  by  two  service-delivery  institutions: 
Uttarakhand  Pey  Jal  Nigam  (UPJN),  created  under  the  Uttarakhand  Uttar  Pradesh  Water 
Supply  and  Sewerage  Act,  1975,  and  responsible  for  capital  works;  and  Uttarakhand  Jal 
Sansthan (UJS), created under the Adaptation and Modification Order, 2002, and in charge of 
operation and maintenance (O&M) of WSS assets. The utilities operate under administrative 
control of the Department of Drinking Water (DDW) and work on a stand-alone basis; ULBs 
have no role in WSS delivery. 
 
B.  Performance of Existing Water Supply and Sewerage Providers 
 
2.  The review of the performance of the existing institutional arrangements indicates the 
following deficiencies.  
 
(i)  WSS  is  centralized  and  is  supply–driven.  There  is  thus  a  lack  of  demand 
responsiveness or stakeholder inclusion in WSS service delivery. 
(ii)  While  both  UPJN  and  UJS  are  supposed  to  be  autonomous  institutions,  in 
practice  both  institutions  work  as  extended  arms  of  the  Uttarakhand  state 
government and experience day-to-day government interference. The absence of 
participative and professional governance, less than optimal institutions, and a 
regulatory regime where the government is both service provider and regulator, 
without the involvement of the end user, are key problems. 
(iii)  There are confusing mandates for UPJN and UJS, both in their statutes and in 
practice. UPJN’s primary task is planning and execution of WSS systems, but in 
some cases it is also involved in the O&M of both urban and rural WSS. UJS is 
responsible for O&M but also sometimes undertakes construction activity. UPJN 
also takes up unrelated construction works on behalf of other departments. 
(iv)  There is a visible lack of coordination between UPJN and UJS, more particularly 
in  the  areas  of  planning  where  a  project  is  usually  taken  up  without  full 
involvement of UJS and ULBs, and without effectively analyzing the lifecycle 
O&M costs and without evaluating different options for technology and cost. 
(v)  Both UPJN and UJS have an engineering orientation and the two organizations 
are lacking in the key areas of management, finance, and human resources. 
(vi)  O&M suffers from high unaccounted-for water, inadequate revenues, and high 
establishment and operational costs, with about one third of operating costs 
recovered from user charges. 
 
C.  Water Utility Improvements 
 
3.  The  Uttarakhand  government  has  already  endorsed  and  committed  to  the  phased 
implementation of the sectoral and institutional reforms in WSS as mandated by the 74th CAA

Appendix 4  33
and JNNURM guidelines. If the gains from substantial investment under the Program are to be 
sustained, there is a need to fully implement reforms in WSS. 
 
4.  During the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) pre-Fact-Finding Mission in May 2007, 
three options for utility improvements were discussed with Uttarakhand government officials and 
other stakeholders. During the Fact-Finding Mission, the major thrust of institutional reforms 
within WSS were further extensively discussed with DDW, UPJN, UJS, the Urban Development 
Department (UDD) (including the UDD secretary), the project director, ULBs, other Uttarakhand 
government officials, and stakeholders. The following guiding principles of the reforms have 
emerged. 
(i)  WSS  improvements  should  be  context-specific  and  sequenced.  They  should 
involve realistic measures with a patient approach to implementation. 
(ii)  Service-delivery function should be separated from policy making and regulation. 
(iii)  Utilities should have clear mandates and act in accordance with their mandate.  
(iv)  A slew of measures should be implemented on utility governance, finance, and 
institutional, operational, and human resource capabilities. 
(v)  Deliberate inclusion of ULBs in WSS delivery through greater representation in 
the board of utilities is to be ensured. 
(vi)  An accountability mechanism should be introduced into UPJN and UJS through 
prior  consultation  and  performance-based  contractual  relationships  with  the 
Uttarakhand  government  and  ULBs,  with  set  indicators  for  performance 
improvements in construction and O&M of WSS. 
 
5.  Within the above overall principles, the following improvements are to be implemented. 
 
6.  Separation  of  Service  Delivery  from  Policy  and  Regulation.  At  present,  policy, 
planning, service delivery, tariff setting, and other regulation in WSS are closely controlled by 
the Uttarakhand government. UPJN and UJS work as an extension of the government and there 
is  no  clear  separation  between  the  policy,  regulatory,  and  service-delivery  functions.  In 
accordance with the Municipal Bill and the JNNURM reforms, the state has already made a 
commitment to separating the regulatory oversight from service delivery for better management. 
While there is a range of options for regulation, there is no need for an elaborate regulatory 
system. The key to efficient, effective, and independent regulation is credible regulation, which 
can initially be a separate small cell within DDW, separated from the policy, planning, and 
service-delivery functions of the WSS sector.
