8.  Participatory  and  Inclusive  Governance.  The  composition  of  the  UPJN  and  UJS 
boards, as well as the Uttarakhand Water and Sewerage Act (1975) (which allows for four local-
government representatives, including one from Dehradun Municipal Corporation in UPJN and 
three representatives from UJS) provide scope for participation of people’s representatives, but 
in practice they have become government-only boards. Key governance improvement needed is 
to ensure that in practice UPJN and UJS have inclusive, participatory boards. The present 
practice of nonconsultation with ULBs at project conceptualization stage is not sustainable. The 
role of ULBs needs to progressively change from being one of passive recipient of WSS 
services to one of active collaborator on the level and type of services desired and paid for. The 
inclusion of ULBs on the board and thus in planning, execution, and O&M of WSS is essential. 
Moreover, for enhanced accountability the boards should have representation from civil society.  
 
9.  Professional and Empowered Management. There is a need to move towards more 
professional and empowered management by (i) bringing experts to the board (there is a 
requirement provision in the statutes to have independent professional representation without 
voting powers), and (ii) changing the relationship of utilities with the state government to one of 
arm’s length, where the relationship shifts from day-to-day government control to the setting and 
monitoring of annual and medium-term targets. Clearly there is a case for devolution of more 
powers, with clearly defined accountability, to the heads of UPJN and UJS. There is also the 
need for changing the unequal status of the two institutions (UJS is headed by a chief general 
manager, whereas UPJN has a managing director), as this seemingly simple issue creates a lot 
of  problems  in  meaningful  coordination  between  the  two  entities  as  well  as  the  effective 
functioning of UJS. Empowerment of UJS management is among the steps that will address the 
issue of coordination, but more importantly will give due primacy to O&M in the urban WSS 
sector, which currently puts a priority on supply-driven asset creation. 
 
10.  Effective  Involvement  of  Urban  Local  Bodies.  Inclusive  governance  in  utilities 
requires that the capabilities of ULBs in WSS are significantly enhanced so that they can play a 
meaningful role in all stages of WSS delivery, including planning, execution, and O&M. This 
gradual transformation will require the transfer and training of a minimum number of WSS staff 
from utilities to ULBs, either permanently or on deputation. Despite the general perception within 
UPJN and UJS regarding understaffing, both have 3,400 staff and it should be possible to have 
some flexibility in human resources such that ULBs can play a greater role in WSS.  
 
11.  Removing the Overlapping Mandate. A key improvement is the removal of distortions 
in the actual working of UPJN and UJS and thus making their roles complementary, which is in 
the spirit of the 1975 statute governing the WSS sector in Uttarakhand. This is central to the 
efficient and effective working of the present vertically separated arrangement. 
 
(i)  UPJN will be responsible for planning and construction activities of the urban 
WSS sector. 
(ii)  O&M in the urban water sector will be the exclusive responsibility of UJS. 
(iii)  The current practice of UPJN doing construction work for other departments will 
need to be discontinued and UPJN should excel in its own area of urban WSS. If 
such  activities  are  necessary  for  augmenting  financial  resources,  UPJN  (as 
permitted by its statute) should take up the work of planning and construction of 
water supply projects in other states. This will enhance the capacity of UPJN. 
(iv)  Urban  water  supply  and  sewerage  is  to  be  planned  by  UPJN  in  close 
consultation with ULBs (the beneficiaries) and UJS (with responsibility for O&M). 
This  will  be  in  conformity  with  revised  JNNURM  guidelines  and  ensure 
complementary  roles  in  the  letter  and  spirit  of  the  Uttarakhand  Water  and 
Sewerage  Act  1975  governing  the  setting  up  and  functioning  of  the  two 
institutions.

12.  Ring-Fencing  of  Water  Supply  and  Sewerage.  At  present,  UPJN  and  UJS  have 
responsibility for managing both urban and rural WSS. As rural and urban WSS are different 
functions, for the sake of accountability it is essential that the urban and rural sections of both 
organizations are separate profit centers. It is also vital that urban and rural organizational, 
human resources, finances, and accounting functions within UPJN and UJS are separated, and 
two stand-alone entities are created—one for handling urban WSS and another for rural WSS 
responsibilities—in each institution. 
 
13.  Tariff Improvements and Reviving Payment Culture. Improving the tariff structures 
and rates and generating revenues so as to at least meet O&M costs are the keys to improving 
utility performance and thus ensuring sustainable WSS delivery. In terms of memoranda or 
understanding signed with the Government under the JNNURM, the Uttarakhand government 
and the three JNNURM cities of Dehradun, Haridwar, and Nainital have committed to 100% 
recovery of O&M costs in urban WSS within 4 years (within 5 years in the case of solid-waste). 
Within 8 years, the state should aim at 100% recovery of O&M in all the towns. In exceptional 
cases,  where  full  recovery  of  O&M  cost  is  not  possible  due  to  physical  and  hydrological 
conditions, extra costs should be segregated and paid separately by the state. The tariff reforms 
of covering at least 100% of O&M cost through user charges in a predetermined feasible time 
frame  has  to  be  accompanied  and  preceded  by  improvement  in  the  billing  and  collection 
efficiencies and substantial improvement in unaccounted for water or ensuring stakeholders 
accept the tariff reforms. There is commitment within the Uttarakhand government and UJS to 
implement phased volumetric charges and metering of the WSS. It is now widely believed that 
people are ready and willing to pay higher tariffs for improved services. 
 
14.  Enhancing Operational, Financial, and Human Resource Capabilities of UPJN and 
UJS. Both the institutions today have essentially an engineering orientation which affects their 
performance. It is necessary that their functional, managerial, operational, financial, and human 
resources are enhanced in a planned way. Similarly, the technical and technological skill levels 
within  both  UPJN  and  UJS  need  to  be  substantially  improved  for  effective  functioning. 
Necessary skill upgrading of human resources to manage WSS planning, execution, and O&M 
is crucial, and organizational and capability skills have to be upgraded. To achieve certain 
targets in line with the JNNURM reform agenda, the following measures are essential: (i) the 
introduction  of  information  technology  and  technological  and  managerial  innovations,  (ii) 
improving the capacity of field staff for improved assessment and control over unaccounted for 
water  (bulk  and  consumer  metering),  and  (iii)  improving  billing  and  collection  efficiencies 
through e-governance and introducing and adjusting periodic volumetric water and sewerage 
tariffs. Lastly, a realistic assessment of the establishment cost and other expenditure of UPJN 
and UJS is called for, and appropriate adjustments are required.  
 
15.  With  regard  to  improvements  in  financial  capabilities,  action  is  needed  in  both 
organizations  (UPJN  and  UJS)  and  the  ULBs.  Improvements  in  financial  capabilities  are 
required both in financial management and in all accounting system and practices. While the 
two institutions already have accrual-based accounting, there are still improvements which 
could  be  made  in  the  actual  use  of  the  management  accounting  tools  for  performance 
evaluation. UPJN’s accounts do not have urban and rural separation and there is definite need 
for clearer monitoring of project accounts. Though UJS does seem to be moving towards 
computerized billing and automation of other functions, the impact is yet to be seen. The 
National Informatics Center-supported computerization of UJS is to be completed within a fixed 
time frame.  
 
16.  Accountability and Performance Enhancement through Contractual Arrangement. 
The present system of subsidy in urban WSS requires change to encourage innovation and 
accountability  and  reward  performance  improvement.  The  option  of  replacing  the  present

FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Summary Financial Management Assessment 
 
1.  Financial Policies. Urban sector financial management has been devolved from the 
Government  of  India  to  each  state  and  urban  local  bodies  (ULBs)  through  the  74th 
Constitutional Amendment Act (CAA) of 1992. As a result of the Act, each state and ULB is 
responsible  for  financial  management,  including  planning,  mobilization,  and  allocation  of 
revenues. This process was further strengthened by the Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban 
Renewal  Mission1  (JNNURM),  which  provides  financial  assistance  to  urban  development 
projects of states, if the states comply with, amongst other things, adoption of (i) modern, 
accrual-based double-entry accounting, (ii) geographic information systems based property tax 
by ULBs with collection efficiency at 85% within the next 7 years, and (iii) reasonable user 
charges by ULBs for operation and maintenance (O&M) cost recovery within the next 7 years. 
 
2.  The state of Uttarakhand, after its separation from Uttar Pradesh in 2000, has not 
formulated  its  own  urban  policy.  ULBs  are  currently  governed  by  the  Uttar  Pradesh  and 
Uttaranchal Municipal Act as amended up to 2001. However, the Uttarakhand government is 
developing municipal law based on the model municipal act, which stipulates greater transfer of 
function from state agencies to ULBs, and reform in user charge and property tax to improve the 
financial position of urban services in the ULBs. Unfortunately, immediate transfer of functions is 
impractical due to the inadequate technical and financial strength of the ULBs. The Uttarakhand 
Urban Sector Development Investment Program will support gradual transfer through capacity 
development at the ULBs. 
 
3.  Investment Program Objective. The objective of the Investment Program is economic 
growth and poverty reduction through provision of urban infrastructure and services, and better 
governance and management in selected major towns. The activities and subprojects under the 
Investment Program are designed to operate within the framework of national and state financial 
policies for the urban sector. For example, the Investment Program will complement the state 
government effort in implementing the financial reform at ULBs proposed under the 74th CAA 
and the JNNURM. Also, the Investment Program will initiate accounting-system reform at the 
state and ULBs, and introduce O&M cost recovery through continuous revision in user charges 
and property tax. An appropriate level of cost recovery will ensure the financial viability of 
investment projects under the Investment Program as assessed in this financial analysis.

(UDD) of the Uttarakhand government will be the Executing Agency (EA) and will establish an

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in India (Uttarakhand):  
 
Uttarakhand has a total population of 8.04 million people, of which 2.18 million are in urban areas (Census 
2001). The urbanization level in the state is 25.5% of the total population in the 2001 census, slightly lower 
than the national average of 27.8%. The urban growth rate of 3.1% exceeds the rural growth rate, which is 
less than 2%. With the high urban growth rates projected to further increase over time, it is expected that 
the level of urbanization will be 37% by 2026—which places the state as the seventh-most urbanized in 
India. The rapid urbanization, a large transient population composed of pilgrims and tourists, and lagging 
infrastructure spending places pressure on urban infrastructure. While 80% of the population has access to 
piped water supply (compared with the national access to improved water sources of 75% in 2005), service 
levels are poor with water available for only 2–4 hours per day at erratic pressures. Per capita supply is 
only 70 liters per day. In the absence of water testing laboratories, the water supply quality is mostly 
unknown. Only 20 towns have sewage treatment facilities and in these towns coverage is only about 50% 
of the urban population. There are no efficient solid-waste management systems in any of the towns.  
 
Uttarakhand is classified as one of the country’s economically stagnant states, where overall poverty is 
over  33%.1  The  urban  population  living  in  slums2  accounts  for  about  17%  of  the  total  state  urban 
population. About 43% of the slums are located on urban fringes and 53% along drains.3 The urban poor’s 
access to basic urban infrastructure is limited, with only 71.4% of the slums covered by piped potable water 
supply,  and  only  42.8%  having  access  to  proper  sanitation  facilities.  These  create  unfavorable 
environmental conditions for poor people, and these threaten public health and reflect the multidimensional 
nature of urban poverty. 
 
The Investment Program is expected to address basic deficiencies across the state and increase economic 
growth potential through improved urban services. Direct benefits will be sustained improvements in basic 
services in all Investment Program areas. The Investment Program will have positive impacts on the poor. 
Safe drinking water is a basic need, which a significant number of poor people in Uttarakhand do not have 
access to. The burden of water collection on vulnerable segments of the population, such as women, will 
be reduced. Improvements in water supply quantity and quality, sewerage and sewage treatment, and 
municipal solid-waste management will lead to public health improvements. This will result in reductions in 
the burden of diseases, treatment cost, and productivity losses, the impacts of which are disproportionately 
experienced  by  poor  people.  Slum  upgrading  subprojects  are  directly  targeted  at  improving  basic 
infrastructure in poor areas. This includes improvements in access roads and community roads including 
drainage improvement and street lighting, provision of bulk water supply and sewerage mains at the entry 
of slum areas, and support for enabling a sustainable environment for improving basic infrastructures in 
slums through policy development. The benefits are expected to be economic growth and direct temporary 
employment in construction work under the Investment Program.

1.  The Investment Program will support the Government of India and the Uttarakhand

service provision in 31 selected towns in Uttarakhand. The Investment Program will support (i) 
water supply; (ii) sewerage and sewage treatment; (iii) municipal solid-waste management; (iv) 
urban  roads  and  traffic  management;  (v)  slum  upgrading  and  poverty  reduction;  and  (vi) 
planning  and  design,  institutional  and  policy  development,  capacity  development,  and 
awareness raising. 
 
2.  The Investment Program will minimize resettlement impacts by prioritizing rehabilitation 
and  optimization  work  within  existing  premises.  New  construction  is  proposed  on  vacant 
Government land where feasible. Tranche 1 subprojects will not require land acquisition. These 
subprojects show that the main resettlement impacts will be due to rehabilitation and laying of 
pipe networks, and these impacts are temporary. Draft short resettlement plans were prepared 
for tranche 1 subprojects in three towns (Supplementary Appendix E).1 Resettlement impacts 
are to be further minimized through careful subproject siting and alignment during detailed 
design and subproject implementation.

B.  Forecasting Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures 
 
2.  The  Investment  Program  is  designed  to  improve  environmental  quality  and  living 
conditions in urban areas through the provision of basic urban services. IEEs conducted for the 
Investment Program show that net subproject environmental benefits are positive and large, and 
include (i) reduced pollution of water resources due to discharge of untreated sewage and 
indiscriminate solid-waste disposal from sewerage and sewage treatment, and municipal solid-
waste  management  investments;  (ii)  increased  availability  of  adequate  potable  water  at 
appropriate  pressure  from  water  supply  subprojects;  (iii)  better  public  health,  particularly 
reduction in waterborne and infectious diseases, through water supply, sewerage and sewage 
treatment, and municipal solid-waste management investments; (iv) improved aesthetics from 
the improvement of urban roads, sewerage and sewage treatment, and municipal solid-waste 
management works; (v) reduced exposure to suspended particulates and noise pollution, and 
increased  pedestrian  safety  through  urban  roads  and  traffic  management;  and  (vi)  social 
benefits from slum improvement and poverty reduction outputs.
